awd_titl_txt: RUI: Discovering New Sources of CP Violation in Flavor Phenomenology
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Bhubanjyoti Bhattacharya at Lawrence Technological University. 

Where is all the antimatter?   Although established theories of particle physics predict that our universe should have roughly similar amounts of matter and antimatter, we see much more matter around us than antimatter.  Matter and antimatter behave similarly under a fundamental symmetry called Charge-Parity, or "CP".  However, processes involving elementary particles may not respect this symmetry.  Discovery of new-physics theories that violate CP will lead to a better understanding of our universe, as they will be able to explain why there is more matter than antimatter.  Physicists expect to find CP-violating new physics in data collected at ongoing worldwide experiments that study elementary-particle collisions.  As part of this research, Professor Bhattacharya will develop new methods of understanding the properties of different types of new physics, with an emphasis on hypothetical particles called "ALPs".  These new particles are important because they can affect CP-violation measurements currently being made at collider experiments.  As such, research in this area advances the national interest by promoting the progress of science, creating a deeper understanding of elementary particles, their properties, and how they interact.  This project is also envisioned to have significant broader impacts.  Working at Lawrence Technological University, a predominantly undergraduate institution, Professor Bhattacharya will actively engage undergraduate students in his research.  By prioritizing recruitment of students from diverse backgrounds, he will promote an environment that fosters inclusion.  Professor Bhattacharya's students will apply newly-developed theoretical methods to analyze data and test new hypotheses about CP violation.  Students conducting research with Professor Bhattacharya will also receive training in computational thinking and acquire transferable skills that will make them successful in future academic or industrial careers. 

More technically, Professor Bhattacharya’s research will reveal complex phases of proposed new couplings in a variety of new-physics models. For example, focusing on data from flavor factories such as the ongoing LHCb and Belle II experiments, Professor Bhattacharya’s research will identify processes affected by ALPs and calculate their effects on CP-violating observables.  Flavor-factory data provide information on the phenomenology of heavy mesons and quarkonia. Professor Bhattacharya’s research will overcome challenges in understanding this data by using approximate flavor symmetries and by quantifying the extent of flavor-symmetry breaking. His research will also develop new methods for the precise determination of CP-violating parameters within the Standard Model of particle physics, such as the Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa angle gamma.   Using computation-driven methods, Professor Bhattacharya and his students will identify how the data deviate from Standard-Model predictions.  By explaining these deviations using new-physics models, Professor Bhattacharya's research will illuminate a path for the discovery of new sources of CP violation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Professor Bhattacharya’s research, funded through this project, had two main objectives: first, to unravel new sources of Charge Parity (CP) violation beyond the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics, and second, to equip undergraduate students at Lawrence Technological University with the skills, expertise, and tools necessary to thrive in America’s dynamic workforce.

Intellectual Merits

Professor Bhattacharya’s projects explored several new methods for understanding CP violation in the SM and beyond. One such project found a unique solution to a long-standing puzzle in hadronic B-meson decays, known as the “B to K pi puzzle.” The measured direct CP asymmetries in two B decay channels have been at odds with expected relationships within the SM. Bhattacharya’s research demonstrated that mixing between the neutral pion and a hypothetical axionlike particle resolves this tension while also addressing issues with the (g-2) of the light leptons.

In a project aligned with the rare and precision frontier of the 2021 US Snowmass Community study, Bhattacharya and his collaborators developed a new Monte Carlo tool to understand how new physics operators affect angular distributions in semileptonic B decays. This tool has been made publicly available for the experimental and theoretical particle physics community. With this tool, Bhattacharya explored a relatively new puzzle in the difference between forward-backward asymmetries in muon and electron channel semileptonic B to D transitions. This research identified discovery prospects for several new “Delta” observables, constructed as differences between angular observables in muon and electron channels, at future electron-positron collider experiments.

Bhattacharya and his collaborators identified puzzles, explored their solutions, and created new pathways for measuring SM observables. Weak hadronic decays of B and D mesons, where the bottom or charm quark decays to light quarks, are often used to study the elements of the Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa (CKM) matrix. The magnitudes and phases of CKM matrix elements encode the strength of the weak-interaction coupling and the SM source of CP violation. However, hadronic decays receive non-perturbative contributions from Quantum Chromodynamics posing a challenge toward meaningful extraction of weak-interaction parameters from experiment. On the other hand, amplitudes for processes involving the light quarks (up, down, and strange) exhibit symmetry when subjected to transformations under the SU(3) group. Bhattacharya’s research exploited this symmetry to establish an equivalence between group theoretic and diagrammatic approaches for understanding the underlying physics of B and D meson decays. Two of these projects resulted in peer-reviewed publications with undergraduate students – one identified an unexpectedly large deviation from the symmetry expectations in two-body B decays, and the other created a new method for measuring the phase of a CKM matrix element in three-body B decays.

These projects have all been oriented toward shedding light on new physics beyond the SM, specifically aiming to uncover new sources of CP violation. They have resulted in several peer-reviewed publications in Physical Review D and the Journal of High Energy Physics. Through invited and contributed talks, Bhattacharya presented his research at multiple national and international conferences and research institutions. Bhattacharya’s students attended many local conferences to present their research and interact with other researchers.

Broader Impacts

Professor Bhattacharya’s projects actively engaged several undergraduate students and equipped them with the tools necessary to lead successful careers in science and technology. One Lawrence Technological University (LTU) student coauthored a peer-reviewed research article with Bhattacharya and his collaborators. After graduating from LTU as the top student in their class, the student went on to a doctoral degree program and subsequently received a graduate research fellowship from the National Science Foundation. Two other students have continued as undergraduates in engineering programs at LTU. The students who worked on Professor Bhattacharya’s projects were exposed to cutting-edge ideas in theoretical physics and particle phenomenology. All students created computer code to analyze data and reported their results in written and oral formats through poster presentations and conference talks. The funded projects were broadly impactful by equipping several undergraduate students with tools spanning multiple disciplines, including physics, mathematics, and computer science.

Bhattacharya was also actively involved in the Community Engagement Frontier of the US Snowmass Community study, where he coauthored an article alongside other Principal Investigators from undergraduate institutions. This article outlined strategies aimed at addressing and overcoming the systemic, structural, and cultural obstacles faced by undergraduate institutions and community colleges. These efforts underscore the powerful impact of collective collaboration in driving meaningful progress and outcomes.
